Document-click (DC) method clusters refinements with similar document click sets
Session-query (SQ) method clusters refinements with similar session co-occurrence queries
6 months of anonymized search query logs split into 10-minute sessions
Top 80 refinements for each query and top 15 clicked docs for each refinement

User Study 400 randomly selected queries from top 10k The order of cluster groups was randomized Each query evaluated by 3 different evaluators Evaluators are experienced side-by-side
evaluators of search results 36 evaluators No more than 36 queries per evaluator

Cohesion [0, 1] Cluster is cohesive if its

We decrease the number of clusters from 50 to 15 in steps of 5
Conclusions Graph clustering formulation based on the realistic
user behavior model Markov Model interpretation to translate the problem
into a vector clustering problem Our method is effective and favored by the users
Future Directions Ambiguous refinements (e.g., milky way) Leveraging clusters to improve user search
